content.text: What is Python?
Python is a programming language - a way to talk to computers using special words and symbols.
Think of it like magic spells:
When you write code in Python, you're giving the computer instructions. The computer follows those instructions exactly, step by step.
Python is one of the most popular languages in the world because:

- It's easy to read (almost like English).
- It's powerful (used in games, websites, AI, robots, and more).
- It's fun (great for making stories, puzzles, and adventures).
In this course, we'll use Python to build a text-based RPG adventure where your hero fights monsters, collects treasure, and saves the kingdom!
The Adventure Begins
Long ago, in the Land of Pythonia, heroes were chosen not by swords, but by their ability to command computers with code.
You are the newest hero. Your journey begins here. But before you can fight monsters, collect treasures, or cast spells... you must learn the first magic spell of programming:
Making the computer speak with your words.
Tags Introduced

- Print
- Comment (bonus)
Concept Notes: Print
The print() function is your hero's voice. It lets you speak to the world of Pythonia. Without it, the story would be silent.
print("Hello, world!")
Output:
Hello, world!
This is the legendary Hello World spell - every programmer's first step.
Advanced Note - Multiple Messages
print("The hero has", 100, "HP.")
Output:
The hero has 100 HP.
Think of this as your hero shouting their stats to the villagers.

lessons.title: Hero Training Drill 1 - Hero's First Words

content.text: Hero Training Drill 1 - Hero's First Words
Mission Briefing: The villagers want to know you are awake.

Print:
"The hero awakens!"
"The adventure begins..."

content.expected_output:
The hero awakens!
The adventure begins...
content.solution:
print("The hero awakens!")
print("The adventure begins...")
hints: Use print() function for each line
Put the text inside quotation marks
Each print() statement creates a new line

content.text: Concept Notes: Comment
Heroes often write notes in their quest log. In Python, these are called comments.
Comments are ignored by the computer - they're just for humans. They start with a #.

# This is the hero's health
hero_hp = 100
Use comments to explain code, leave reminders, or just write funny thoughts for future heroes.

lessons.title: Hero Training Drill 2 - Notes from the Guild Master

content.text: Hero Training Drill 2 - Notes from the Guild Master
Mission Briefing: The guild master leaves a note at the top of your scroll.

Write a comment:
# This is my first Python program

Print:
"The guild welcomes the hero!"

content.solution:
# This is my first Python program
print("The guild welcomes the hero!")
hints: Comments start with #
Comments don't affect the output
Use print() for the message

content.text: Challenge Quest - The Prologue
Story: Your hero awakens in a quiet village. The villagers gather to see the chosen one.
Your Mission: Use print() to tell at least three sentences about your hero's awakening.

content.expected_output:
The hero awakens in a small village.
The villagers gather around.
The adventure begins...
content.solution:
print("The hero awakens in a small village.")
print("The villagers gather around.")
print("The adventure begins...")
hints: Write at least 3 print() statements
Be creative with your story
Each print() creates a new line

content.text: By the End of Week 1:

- Kids understand what Python is (a language like magic spells).
- They can use print() to make their hero speak.
- They know how to use comments as quest notes.
- They've written the Prologue of their RPG story - the hero's awakening!
Next week: the hero will need stats (HP, coins, weapons). We'll learn about variables and data types to give the hero strength.

lessons.title: Week 1 Remedial Lesson - Extra Practice with Print & Comments

content.text: This remedial lesson is for heroes who need extra practice with Week 1 concepts. It is divided into two independent parts: Print and Comment. You can study only the part where you need more help.
Concept: What Does Print Do?
The print() function makes the computer say something on the screen.

- Text (words or sentences) -> Put inside quotation marks " ".
- Numbers -> Can be written directly without quotes.
- Commas -> Connect text and numbers so they appear together.
- Each print() -> Starts on a new line.
Think of print() as your hero's voice spell - every time you use it, the world hears your hero speak.
Examples
print("The hero wakes up.")
Output:
The hero wakes up.
print(2025)
Output:
print("The hero has", 30, "coins.")
Output:
The hero has 30 coins.

print("The hero opens the door.")
print("A monster appears!")
Output:

The hero opens the door.
A monster appears!
Practice Drills for Print
Drill P1 - The Village Bell

Task: Write two print() lines.
- First line: "The village bell rings."
- Second line: "The villagers run to the square."
- Think of this as your hero describing what happens in the town.

content.expected_output:
The village bell rings.
The villagers run to the square.
content.solution:
print("The village bell rings.")
print("The villagers run to the square.")
hints: Use two separate print() statements
Put each sentence in quotation marks
Each print() creates a new line

content.text: Drill P2 - Hero Stats

Task: Write one print() line.
- Show the hero's health points (HP).
- Sentence should look exactly like: The hero has 45 HP.
- Hint: Use commas so you can combine text and the number 45.

hints: Use commas to separate text and numbers
The number doesn't need quotation marks
Format: print("text", number, "text")

content.text: Drill P3 - Your Own Scene

Task: Write three print() lines to tell your own short story.
- Each line should describe a different moment.
- Example ideas:
  Line 1: What the hero sees (forest, cave, castle).
  Line 2: What happens next (monster appears, villagers cheer).
  Line 3: What the hero does (draws a sword, runs away).

content.expected_output:
The forest is dark and quiet.
A strange owl hoots from the trees.
The hero lights a torch.
content.solution:
print("The forest is dark and quiet.")
print("A strange owl hoots from the trees.")
print("The hero lights a torch.")
hints: Be creative with your story
Write three separate print() statements
Each line should describe a different action or scene

content.text: Concept: What Are Comments?
Comments are notes inside your code.

- Start with a #.
- Python ignores them.
- They're written only for humans to read.
Think of comments as your quest log notes. They remind you what the code does, just like scribbles in a hero's notebook.
Examples

# This line prints the hero's greeting
print("Hello, traveler!")

# The hero's health points
print("HP: 80")

# The dragon snores loudly here, but Python doesn't care!
print("The dragon is sleeping.")
Practice Drills for Comment
Drill C1 - The Scroll Header

Task: At the top of your program, write a comment.
- The comment should say: # This is my practice scroll
- Then write one print() line: The practice begins!

content.solution:
# This is my practice scroll
print("The practice begins!")
hints: Comments start with #
Comments don't produce output
The print() statement comes after the comment

content.text: Drill C2 - Explain Your Line

Task: Write a program with two lines.
  Line 1: A comment explaining what the code does.
  Example: # This line prints the sword discovery
  Line 2: A print statement that shows: The hero finds a sword.

content.solution:
# This line prints the sword discovery
print("The hero finds a sword.")
hints: First line should be a comment with #
Second line should be print() statement
Comments help explain what the code does

content.text: Drill C3 - Write Your Own Notes

Task: Create a mini-program with at least two comments and two print() lines.
- Think of the comments as your hero's notes explaining the story.

Example structure:
# Hero enters the cave
print("The cave is cold and dark.")
# Hero lights a torch
print("The torch glows brightly.")

content.expected_output:
The cave is cold and dark.
The torch glows brightly.
content.solution:
# Hero enters the cave
print("The cave is cold and dark.")
# Hero lights a torch
print("The torch glows brightly.")
hints: Alternate between comments and print() statements
Comments explain what's happening
Print statements create the actual output
